description:
Noctua janthe, commonly known as the Lesser Quadrangle, is a species of night-flying moth that belongs to the family Noctuidae. It is a medium-sized moth with a wingspan of approximately 35-45 millimeters.

The forewings of Noctua janthe are typically a greyish-brown color, with distinct darker markings and a pale outer margin. The hindwings are greyish-white, sometimes with a faint darker border. The moth has a slender body and relatively small, rounded antennae.

Noctua janthe is widely distributed across Europe, from the Iberian Peninsula to the Ural Mountains, and can be found in a variety of habitats, including grasslands, heathlands, and deciduous forests. The larvae, or caterpillars, of this species feed on a range of low-growing plants, such as various grasses and herbaceous plants.

The life cycle of Noctua janthe includes an egg stage, larval (caterpillar) stage, pupal stage, and the adult moth stage. The adults are typically active at night, attracted to light sources, and can be observed from late summer to early autumn.
